title: 113_hr345
content: The Act titled "District of Columbia Budget Autonomy Act of 2013" terminates federal mandates over the local budget process and financial management of the District of Columbia. It amends the District of Columbia Home Rule Act to end federal mandates. The District of Columbia Budget Autonomy Act of 2013 eliminates federal mandates on the local budget process and financial management. It establishes that the District of Columbia will govern its budget and financial management under its own laws, starting from fiscal year 2014. The District of Columbia Budget Autonomy Act of 2013 removes the requirement for the District to follow federal fiscal year rules from 2014 onwards. It does not absolve the District of any financial obligations incurred before fiscal year 2014. The Act does not waive any provisions except those not applicable to the fiscal year in question. The table of contents of the District of Columbia Budget Autonomy Act of 2013 is amended by adding items related to part D of title IV. Sec. 458 of the District of Columbia Budget Autonomy Act of 2013 terminates Federal mandates. It eliminates the Congressional review period for budget acts and specifies the effective date for Acts adopting the annual budget for the District of Columbia government. Additionally, Section 3 terminates Federal mandates over borrowing of money. Sec. 3 terminates Federal mandates over borrowing of money under the District of Columbia Home Rule Act. Sec. 490A states that borrowing by the District of Columbia will be governed by District laws, except for specific provisions related to full faith and credit, tax treatment of bonds, and legal investment. Section 490A outlines the specific provisions governing borrowing by the District of Columbia, including legal investment in bonds, payments for various projects, and contributions to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority. It also includes a rule of construction to ensure that existing obligations and federal laws regarding borrowing funds are not waived. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding items relating to part E of title IV. The text chunk discusses the termination of federal mandates and the repeal of the cap on the amount of district borrowing. Additionally, it mentions the repeal of the application of the Federal Anti-Deficiency Act to the District of Columbia government. The text chunk discusses the repeal of limitations on appropriations and apportionment of appropriations for the District of Columbia government. It includes amendments to various sections in title 31 of the United States Code. The text chunk amends various sections in title 31 of the United States Code by removing references to the Mayor of the District of Columbia. The amendments apply to fiscal year 2014 and onwards. SEC. 5. Other amendments to Home Rule Act related to changes in federal role in budget process. Amendments to the District of Columbia Home Rule Act give federal authority over the budget-making process during control years. The Council and Mayor are restricted from approving budgets that are not consistent with the financial plan established under the Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Act of 1995. The term "control year" is defined within the Act. The term "control year" is defined in section 305(4) of the District of Columbia Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Act of 1995. The amendments made by this section will apply to fiscal year 2014 and each subsequent fiscal year. SEC. 6. OTHER CONFORMING AMENDMENTS RELATING TO FEDERALLY AUTHORIZED ADJUSTMENTS TO LOCAL APPROPRIATIONS. Authority granted by the federal government to increase spending in case of general fund surplus and increased revenue collections is amended for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 and any control year thereafter. The authority granted by the federal government regarding the use of federally mandated reserve funds is amended for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 and any control year thereafter.
